title: Cyclist’s Distance
problem_text: A cyclist travels at 12 km/h for 3 hours. How far does he travel?
solution_hints: Use Distance = Speed × Time.
Multiply 12 km/h by 3 h.
common_pitfalls: Adding instead of multiplying speed and time.
Forgetting to state the unit (km).

title: Car’s Average Speed
problem_text: A car travels 180 km in 3 hours. What is its average speed?
solution_hints: Speed = Distance ÷ Time.
Divide 180 km by 3 h.
common_pitfalls: Multiplying distance and time instead of dividing.
Giving answer in km instead of km/h.

title: Jogger’s Time
problem_text: A jogger runs 5 km at a speed of 8 km/h. How long does he take? (Give your answer in minutes.)
solution_hints: Time = Distance ÷ Speed.
Convert hours to minutes by ×60.
common_pitfalls: Using Speed ÷ Distance instead of Distance ÷ Speed.
Forgetting to convert 0.625 h to minutes.

title: Train Speed Conversion
problem_text: A train travels at 90 km/h. What is its speed in m/s?
solution_hints: Recall 1 km = 1000 m and 1 h = 3600 s.
Multiply 90 by 1000, then divide by 3600.
common_pitfalls: Dividing by 60 instead of 3600.
Forgetting to convert kilometres to metres.

title: Two-Segment Trip
problem_text: John drove 120 km at 60 km/h and then 80 km at 80 km/h. What was his average speed for the whole trip?
solution_hints: Average Speed = Total Distance ÷ Total Time.
Find time for each segment, add them, then divide.
common_pitfalls: Averaging 60 and 80 directly (giving 70 km/h).
Forgetting to convert 0.5 h from decimals to fractions if required.
verified_methodology: Step 3: Total distance = 200 km; total time = 3 h.

title: Cycling There and Back
problem_text: Amy cycled from Town A to Town B at 15 km/h. She returned at 10 km/h and took 30 minutes longer on the return trip. What is the distance between Town A and Town B?
solution_hints: Let the distance be d km.
Set up an equation for the difference in times.
Remember 30 minutes = 0.5 h.
common_pitfalls: Using 30 minutes as 30 h.
Adding instead of subtracting the two times.

title: Bird’s Flight Distance
problem_text: A bird flies at 18 m/s. How far will it fly in 4 minutes?
solution_hints: Convert 4 minutes to seconds (×60).
Multiply speed by time, then convert metres to kilometres.
common_pitfalls: Multiplying 18 by 4 without converting units.
Forgetting that 1000 m = 1 km.

title: Walk-and-Jog Average
problem_text: Serene walked at 5 km/h for 30 minutes and then jogged at 9 km/h for 20 minutes. What was her average speed for the whole journey?
solution_hints: Find distance for each part using D = S × T.
Convert minutes to hours.
Average Speed = Total Distance ÷ Total Time.
common_pitfalls: Adding speeds directly (5 + 9).
Using 20/100 instead of 20/60 for hours.
verified_methodology: Step 4: Total time = 0.5 h + 0.333… h = 0.833… h.

title: Meeting Time
problem_text: Two pupils start walking towards each other from points 1.2 km apart. One walks at 60 m/min and the other at 40 m/min. How long will they take to meet?
solution_hints: Convert all speeds to the same unit (m/min).
Add the two speeds to get relative speed.
Time = Distance ÷ Relative Speed.
common_pitfalls: Subtracting the speeds instead of adding.
Leaving distance in kilometres and speed in m/min.

title: Train Passing a Lamp-Post
problem_text: A 120 m long train passes a lamp-post in 12 seconds. What is the train’s speed in km/h?
solution_hints: Speed = Length ÷ Time gives m/s.
Convert m/s to km/h (×3.6).
common_pitfalls: Using 12 ÷ 120 instead of 120 ÷ 12.
Multiplying by 60 instead of 3.6 to convert.

title: Round-Trip Average Speed
problem_text: A car travels from town X to town Y at 80 km/h and returns at 60 km/h. What is its average speed for the whole journey?
solution_hints: Let the one-way distance be d km.
Average Speed = 2d ÷ (d/80 + d/60).
Simplify the expression.
common_pitfalls: Averaging 80 and 60 directly (giving 70 km/h).
Dividing total distance by the average of the times.

title: Pace to Speed
problem_text: A marathon runner maintains a pace of 5 minutes per kilometre. What is his speed in km/h?
solution_hints: 1 km in 5 min ⇒ find km in 60 min.
common_pitfalls: Multiplying 5 by 60 (giving 300 km/h).
Leaving answer in km/min.

title: Bus B Catches Up
problem_text: Bus A leaves a station at 8 a.m. travelling at 45 km/h. Bus B leaves the same station at 9 a.m. on the same route at 65 km/h. At what time will Bus B catch up with Bus A?
solution_hints: Find Bus A’s head-start distance after 1 hour.
Relative speed = 65 km/h − 45 km/h.
Time to catch up = Head start ÷ Relative speed, then add to 9 a.m.
common_pitfalls: Adding the two speeds instead of subtracting.
Forgetting that Bus B starts 1 hour later.
verified_methodology: Step 1: Head-start distance = 45 km (Bus A in its first hour).
Step 3: Time to catch up = 45 ÷ 20 = 2.25 h = 2 h 15 min.

title: Arriving On Time
problem_text: A bus is scheduled to travel 210 km in 3 h 30 min. Due to traffic, it averages 50 km/h for the first 2 hours. What must its average speed be for the remaining distance in order to arrive on time?
solution_hints: Calculate distance covered in the first 2 h.
Find remaining distance and remaining time.
Required speed = Remaining distance ÷ Remaining time.
common_pitfalls: Using 3.5 h − 2 h = 2 h remaining (should be 1.5 h).
Subtracting instead of dividing when finding required speed.
verified_methodology: Step 1: Distance in first 2 h = 50 × 2 = 100 km.
Step 4: Required speed = 110 ÷ 1.5 = 73 ⅓ km/h ≈ 73.3 km/h.
